Thus, $QD=SF=1$ and $RE=r$. Join $QR$, $RS$, $PS$, $PQ$, and $PR$. Since we are connecting centers of tangent circles, $PQ=PS=2$ and $QR=RS=PR=1+r$. Join $QS$.

By symmetry, $PRE$ is a straight line (that is, $PE$ passes through $R$). Since $QS$ is parallel to $BC$, $QS$ is perpendicular to $PR$, meeting at $Y$. Since $QD=1$, $YE=1$. Since $RE=r$, $YR=1-r$. Since $QR=1+r$, $YR=1-r$ and $\triangle QYR$ is right-angled at $Y$, then by the Pythagorean Theorem, \begin{align}

QY^2 &= QR^2 - YR^2\\ &= (1+r)^2 - (1-r)^2 \\ &= (1+2r+r^2)-(1-2r+r^2) \\ &= 4r. \end{align}Since $PR=1+r$ and $YR=1-r$, then $PY = PR-YR=2r$. Since $\triangle PYQ$ is right-angled at $Y$, \begin{align}

PY^2 + YQ^2 & = PQ^2 \\ (2r)^2 + 4r & = 2^2 \\ 4r^2 + 4r & =4 \\ r^2 + r - 1 & = 0. \end{align}By the quadratic formula, $r = \dfrac{-1\pm \sqrt{1^2-4(1)(-1)}}{2} = \dfrac{-1\pm\sqrt{5}}{2}$. Since $r>0$, then $r = \dfrac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}$ (which is the reciprocal of the famous ``golden ratio").

assumes h0 : "dist P Q = dist Q R = dist R S = dist S P = 1"
and h1 : "dist P ABC = dist Q ABC = dist R ABC = dist S ABC = 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b c. a * (dist P R) powr 2 + b * (dist P R) = c \<longrightarrow> r = (a + sqrt b) / c"
shows  "a + b + c = 6"
